Color Palette

Color brings software to life. Like typography, it speaks to users in different ways. It can attract the eye to certain focal points, help users know what to do next and indicate changes in a system.

How to use

Reference all color variables with one line of code.

@import file required!

Please note that all Sass files using color variables require a file import of x1-ui-bootstrap/dist/app/src/x1-ui-sass-tools.scss from you bower component directory.

@import "../bower_components/x1-ui-bootstrap/dist/app/src/x1-ui-sass-tools.scss";

.example-class {
	background-color: $white;
}

Examples

Use the color variables at different scales with Sass mixins: opacity and mix.

Warning!

Please note that using the opacity mixin does not create a color, it will reveal what's underneath the element through transparency.

				// #00a6a0 with 50% opacity
.opacity-teal {
	background-color: rgba($teal, 0.5);
}

// #00a6a0 with 25% #ffffff
.lighten-teal {
	background-color: mix($white, $teal, 25%);
}

// #00a6a0 with 25% #231F20
.darken-teal {
	background-color: mix($black, $teal, 25%);
}
Search by variable name or hex value to filter the color swatches below.
{{color.variable}} {{color.hex}}

What it does...

Through contrast, emphasis, and visual appeal, color enhances the user's understanding of UI elements and assists the user in understanding information. Color is applied purposefully to enhance meaning, create clear hierarchies and complement photography.

Judicious use of color can make your UI more effective. Color can help users understand certain meanings at a glance. Color can also make your product appear more aesthetically pleasing and refined. When used effectively, color can help the user understand the information presented. Color must never be the only way to communicate context and meaning in your UI--it should only assist in understanding. This restriction is primarily due to accessibility, as not all people see color the same way.

Peretz uses a subset of the IBM Design Language colors. Within the Peretz palette, we created color groups for specific purposes. These groups avoid unpleasant color combinations in the UI and reinforce meaning. For example, having separate colors for navigation and charting emphasizes the distinction between the two. This color blueprint reflects the colors in the IBM Design Language at the time it was created. When changes are made to the IBM palette, there might be changes to the Peretz palette to reflect the changes in the IBM Design Language.

IBM Commerce teal

In IBM Commerce, we’ve taken the teal from the IBM design language as our primary accent color. A consistent strong color enables us to build a consistent set of recognizable IBM Commerce products and helps us create a delightful user experience. Teal evokes feelings of calmness as well as security and trust, which are important parts of our overall story.

That said, we do not want an all-teal interface. Use teal sparingly and strategically in order to focus the user on important sections within the page.

The rule of thumb is to use teal when you want to draw the user to certain aspects of your interface. Don’t use teal everywhere as it will overwhelm your users, and they won’t know which elements are important.

When it works

In this example, teal is used as an accent color to create visual hierarchy on the call to action buttons.

In this example, teal draws attention to interactions, both in the storyboard and in the palette.

When it doesn't work

This overuse of teal can be misleading to what areas are buttons, headers, or accent details within the report.
